transcripts.text: I'm here at Netroots Nation 2019 with Carl Cameron from Front Page Live.  He's the chief political director there.  Carl, thank you so much for joining us.
Entirely my pleasure.  It's great to be here with you at Netroots.

Now, you may recognize Carl because he was a prime face on Fox News, but now he is very much at the front lines of running Front Page Live, which is a progressive news site.  Can we talk about how you made the switch?
Sure.  I worked at Fox for 22 years.  uh...
before they were fax when fax actually i started before they watch.
originally fax wasn't always what it is today.

no one fox launched a fox news channel launch.  uh... it was the third attempt by rupert murdoch to do one and when i was hired it wasn't by roger ailes it was by a different president of the company named joe parent and who had been the president of cbs news And my immediate boss was Emily Rooney, who was the daughter of Andy Rooney, the famous guy on... I'm a big fan.  ...who was very funny over the years.

So, initially, for the first several years, it really was fair and balanced, and Fox was very, very disciplined about pointing out that if somebody was from a particular organization, they would say this is leaning right, leaning left, leaning libertarian, whatever it might be.  And over time, the rating...
Well, let's not go there, because we kind of know what happened.  ...rough, right?

Cable news is a business.  And the executives at Fox determined that giving conservatives news that would keep their eyeballs in front of the TV would ultimately get them more eyeballs on Geico commercials, which meant money and the rest.

And here we are, capitalism playing its role in our news media.  So you're a very great person to talk to about, because Fox has been very successful at getting those talking points out and really you know, getting involved in our political process, and now how can we on the left do that?

Well, the first thing is, at Fox, there was an overabundance of entertainment and opinion and ideology as opposed to factual news in the news division.  The news division was there, but it atrophied compared to what the entertainment side was doing.  And the lesson that Democrats need to understand is that long before the World Wide Web started, by the way, the first presidential election with the World Wide Web was 96.  This is still pretty new stuff.  Ten years later, from the first web pages, then we had the first president elected by Cambridge Analytica and Facebook instead of by the electorate.  So understanding digital is incredibly important in media.  Understanding the difference between opinion and ideology and fact is incredibly important.  And then comes the difference in a two-party system, which is what we've got.  That's not what the Constitution envisioned.  We've had over 100 parties on presidential ballots over the course of this country's lifetime.  So we can have more than two parties.  But in a two-party system, when one party loses its way, Our entire system breaks down.  The Republicans have lost their way, helping to elect and now helping to serve a president who is neither a Republican nor a Democrat, although he ran for president once as a Reform Party candidate.  making a lie to his original origin story that he was not a politician and had never run for office.
Carl, I'm sorry to cut you off in the middle of this, but we only have about a minute left, and I want to make sure that people understand what Front Page Live is.

Front Page Live is an aggregator of progressive and liberal news, but it is all fact-based.  It is going to come from mainstream operations, but it'll be deliberately curated for people on the left.  People on the right and in the center will have to come to it because it's so relevant.  It will be fact-checked.  If there's a mistake made by a journalist, we will even tell you that the story that you read yesterday was a mistake.  And at the end of this, this is very important, you'll know that it is the most viral and trending, so you'll know that other eyeballs are watching it.  And if you're really offended or inspired, you can hit on a button which will bring you to organizations where you can actually get involved, even if it's to get a newsletter or to make a donation or get to work.

And what about the fact that so much media that we have out there right now has a corporate spin to it?  So even if the facts are right, they still have a certain corporate spin.  For example, the New York Times just covered a story about Venezuela where they didn't mention that U.S.  sanctions are actually causing some of the poverty there.  What are we going to do about that?

The media has to get back to basics and understand that Journalism is atrophying at the local and state level.  And if we traffic in ideas and ideology, our credibility will take a huge hit and the atrophy will go to the national level as well.  The distrust is corrosive in this country.  It's not the way we're supposed to be doing things.
Thank you so much, Carl.  I appreciate it.  You can find the new project at Front Page Live on the Internet.  We'll be back with more.
